questions.text: A patient with right orbital cellulitis is not responding to antibiotics and is seen to be worsening after the initial presentation. The first sign to raise the suspicion of involvement contralateral is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Paralysis of Left Lateral Rectus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paralysis of Left Lateral Rectus Orbital cellulitis refers to an acute infection of soft tissues of orbit behind the orbital septum. A thin tissue that divides the eyelid from the eye socket. Causative organisms - Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes , and influenza. Clinical features Swelling and severe pain , which increases with eye movements Associated with general symptoms like fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration LOV and / or diplopia Swelling of lids, characterized by woody hardness and redness Chemosis of conjunctiva Axial proptosis Restriction of ocular movements RAPD Fundus examination reveals papillitis and papilledema

Highyeild:

Complications- optic neuritis CRAO Subperiosteal abscess Orbital abscess Temporal or parotid abscess Cavernous sinus thrombosis Septicemia or pyaemia

Extraedge:

Investigation- bacterial culture Complete hemogram X-ray PNS Orbital USG CT and MRI

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain, swelling, erythema of the left eyelid, and double vision. On examination, there is proptosis, gaze restriction, and periorbital edema. Vitals are pulse 98 bpm, BP 108/72, Temperature 100° F. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Orbital Cellulitis This is a case of orbital cellulitis with extensive lids swelling with chemosis, proptosis, and impaired mobility resulting in diplopia. Pain is severe , increased by movement of the eye or pressure. Fever is presen t, and cerebral symptoms may arise.

Highyeild:

Complications- optic neuritis CRAO Subperiosteal abscess Orbital abscess Temporal or parotid abscess Cavernous sinus thrombosis Septicemia or pyaemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Preseptal cellulitis commonly presents as a swelling of the lids, erythema, and chemosis, often conjunctival discharge There is no proptosis or restriction of ocular movements or visual function, differentiating between preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis. Option: C .Conjunctivitis presents with symptoms and signs of discomfort, foreign body sensation, photophobia, discharge from the eyes (type of discharge depending on the cause), conjunctival congestion, and chemosis,e., swelling of the conjunctiva. Option: D. Keratitis or inflammation of the cornea presents with pain, foreign body sensation, redness and watering from eyes, photophobia, blurring of vision, chemosis of the conjunctiva, and corneal ulcer.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain, swelling of eyelids, erythema of the right eye, and a diminution of vision. On examination, there is proptosis and gaze restriction. Vitals are pulse 100 bpm, BP 106/74, Temperature 100° F. What are the possible causes of reduced vision in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retrobulbar Neuritis The clinical vignette describes a case of orbital cellulitis due to symptoms and signs like pain, swelling of eyelids, proptosis, and gaze restriction. Vision may be reduced in orbital cellulitis due to retrobulbar neuritis, compression of the optic nerve or its blood supply due to raised tissue pressure caused by inflammatory oedema of the extraocular muscles, orbital fat, and congested veins.

Highyeild:

Orbital cellulitis refers to an acute infection of soft tissues of orbit behind the orbital septum. A thin tissue that divides the eyelid from the eye socket. Causative organisms - Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, and H. influenza.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Branch retinal artery occlusion describes decreased arterial blood flow to the retina leading to ischemic damage. The severity of visual loss depends upon the area of retinal tissue affected by the vascular occlusion. However, it is painless, unlike this case. Option: C . Retinal detachment (RD) is characterized by transient flashes of light (photopsia), ‘floaters’ or a ‘curtain’ or ‘veil’ obscuring the field of vision. Option: D. Vitreous haemorrhage presents with sudden development of floaters or sudden painless loss of vision in massive vitreous haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the OPD with pain, erythema of the right eye, eyelid swelling, and a diminution of vision for a few hours. On examination, there is proptosis and gaze restriction. Orbital cellulitis is suspected. Which of the following organisms is most commonly responsible for the disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Staphylococcus aureus The most frequently isolated organisms in cases of orbital cellulitis are Staphylococcus and Streptococcus , followed by H. influenzae, Pseudomonas, E. coli , etc. In diabetics, a particularly fulminant infection with Mucor or Aspergillus is possible.

Highyeild:

Orbital cellulitis refers to an acute infection of soft tissues of orbit behind the orbital septum. A thin tissue that divides the eyelid from the eye socket. Vision may be reduced in orbital cellulitis due to retrobulbar neuritis, compression of the optic nerve or its blood supply due to raised tissue pressure caused by inflammatory oedema of the extraocular muscles, orbital fat, and congested veins.

Proteus species can cause conjunctivitis, canaliculitis, dacryocystitis, and even progress into preseptal cellulitis. However, it is not the most common cause. Option: D. E. Coli can lead to orbital cellulitis; however, it is not the most common cause.

On examination, there is proptosis, gaze restriction, and periorbital edema. Vitals are pulse 94 bpm, BP 100/68 mmHg, temperature 100° F. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.label: D
options.text: Blood samples for culture and sensitivity

questions.correct_answer: D. Blood samples for culture and sensitivity
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blood samples for culture and sensitivity This is a case of orbital cellulitis . The initial step among the given options would be to take blood samples for culture , followed by intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient presents with pain, right eyelid swelling, erythema, and excessive eye watering. There is chemosis, periorbital edema, proptosis, and gaze restriction on examination. A CT scan shows the following findings. What is the management of the condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IV antibiotics This is a case of orbital cellulitis from the symptoms and signs. The CT scan shows soft tissue swelling of the orbit. Treatment includes administration of intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs.

Investigation- bacterial culture Complete hemogram X-ray PNS Orbital USG CT and MRI

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Evisceration is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. It is done in conditions like panophthalmitis, a complication of orbital cellulitis. However, intravenous antibiotics are the most appropriate and initial management of this case. Options: C and D. Topical timolol and topical pilocarpine are used to manage glaucoma, which can also present with erythema of the eyes. However, swelling of eyelids and proptosis are not seen in glaucoma
